Title:
Comparative phylogeography reveals consistently shallow
genetic diversity in Antarctic bdelloid rotifers
Keywords:
diversification, endemism, phylogeography, population
genetics, Rotifera.
Abstract:
Aim: We test whether the unique history of isolation and
harsh ecological conditions of Antarctica could affect the patterns of
genetic diversity in bdelloid rotifers, a group of microscopic aquatic
and limno-terrestrial animals. Location: focus on Antarctica, in
comparison to data from all over the world. Taxon: Rotifera Bdelloidea.
Methods: We analysed different metrics of genetic diversity, also
spatially explicit ones, including number of haplotypes, accumulation
curves, genetic distances, time to the most recent common ancestor,
number of independently evolving units from DNA taxonomy, strength of
the correlation between geographic and genetic distances, population
genetics neutrality and differentiation indices, potential historical
processes, obtained from an extensive sample of cytochrome oxidase
subunit I (COI). We analysed 2244 individuals from 23 species in a
comparison between Antarctic and non-Antarctic species, subdivided into
a dataset of nine well-sampled species to provide reliable inference,
and a secondary dataset of 14 less well-sampled species to support the
generality of the results obtained from the main dataset. Results:
Antarctic species had consistently lower genetic diversity and younger
age than non-Antarctic species, even if they were similar in sample
size, geographical extent, neutrality and differentiation indices, and
correlation between genetic and geographic distances. Main conclusions:
The extensive survey of genetic diversity in one mitochondrial marker in
Antarctic bdelloids support the previous suggestions from other
organisms that the origin of terrestrial Antarctic fauna occurred
through extinctions and not new adaptations, that the harsh conditions
have maintained a reduced genetic diversity, and that also in Antarctica
biogeographical barriers may have an effect on structuring genetic
diversity in space.
